snippet: After the death of its most beloved leader, the African National Congress could face its most competitive elections since it came to power in 1994.
abstract: African National Congress will face what may be its most fiercely competitive election since it came to power in 1994, and will do so without Nelson Mandela, its most important moral figure; there are signs that the party could slip below 60 percent of the vote, an important psychological figure for a party accustomed to landslides.

byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish contributed reporting from Soweto, South Africa.

lead_paragraph: After the death of its most beloved leader, the African National Congress could face its most competitive elections since it came to power in 1994.

headline.main: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
headline.print_headline: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
